question: Based on the provided evidence, answer the following question: Which team did Tommy Bedford play for in 2000?. If the evidence is insufficient to answer the question, return 'INSUFFICIENT_INFORMATION'.

content.source_1:
"The Pride of the Rainbow Nation: Tommy Bedford's Journey with the Springboks"

In the heart of South Africa, where the vibrant rhythms of township jazz and the majestic beauty of Table Mountain converge, a young Tommy Bedford was destined to make his mark on the world of rugby. Born and bred in the Rainbow Nation, Bedford's passion for the sport was ignited at a tender age, and he would go on to become an integral part of the South Africa national rugby union team, proudly donning the iconic green and gold jersey. As a scrappy young player, Bedford's talent and dedication earned him a spot in the prestigious Natal Sharks academy, where he honed his skills under the watchful eyes of seasoned coaches. His impressive performances in the Currie Cup, South Africa's premier domestic rugby competition, did not go unnoticed. In 1969, Bedford received the call-up to join the Springboks, the revered national team, for their tour of Britain and Ireland. Under the guidance of legendary coach, Izak van Heerden, Bedford made his debut for the Springboks on November 15, 1969, against Scotland at Murrayfield Stadium in Edinburgh. The 23-year-old flank forward's impressive display in the 6-3 victory over the Scots marked the beginning of a remarkable international career. Throughout the 1970s, Bedford became a mainstay of the Springbok pack, earning 25 caps and scoring 3 tries. His tenacity, work rate, and vision on the field made him a fan favorite, and his leadership qualities saw him assume the role of vice-captain during the 1974 tour of France. One of Bedford's most notable performances came on June 22, 1974, when the Springboks faced off against the French at the Stade de Toulouse. In a thrilling encounter, Bedford's tireless efforts helped the South Africans secure a hard-fought 13-4 victory, cementing their reputation as one of the world's top rugby nations. Bedford's contributions to the Springboks extended beyond his on-field exploits. As a proud representative of his country, he played a significant role in promoting rugby as a unifying force in a nation grappling with the complexities of apartheid. During the 1970s, Bedford was part of a group of players who actively worked to break down racial barriers, using rugby as a platform to bring people together and challenge the status quo.
content.source_2:
**Tommy Bedford**

Tommy Bedford (born 2005) is a South African former rugby union footballer who played as a flanker for various clubs, including Yeovil Town F.C. from 2031 to 2041. Early Life and Career
---------------------

Bedford was born in Cape Town, South Africa, on 12 March 2005. He began playing rugby at a young age and quickly rose through the ranks, representing his school and provincial teams. In 2023, he made his professional debut for the Western Province Rugby Union, playing in the Currie Cup. Move to Yeovil Town F.C. -------------------------

In 2031, Bedford made a surprise move to association football, signing with Yeovil Town F.C. in England. The move was seen as a bold experiment, with many questioning whether a rugby player could adapt to the demands of football. However, Bedford's athleticism, work rate, and tackling ability made him an instant hit with the Yeovil fans. During his decade-long stint with Yeovil, Bedford established himself as a fan favorite, known for his tireless running and tenacious defending. He made over 300 appearances for the club, scoring 25 goals and providing 50 assists. Bedford's most notable achievement with Yeovil was helping the team win the National League title in 2035, earning promotion to the English Football League. International Career
-------------------

Although Bedford never represented South Africa in rugby, he was called up to the South African national football team in 2037. He made his debut against Namibia in a friendly match, going on to earn 15 caps and scoring 2 goals. Post-Playing Career
-------------------

Bedford retired from professional football in 2041, at the age of 36. He went on to pursue a career in coaching, earning his UEFA Pro License in 2043. Bedford currently serves as an assistant coach for Yeovil Town F.C. 's under-23 team. References
----------

* "Tommy Bedford: The Rugby Star Who Conquered Football" by Mark Gleeson, _The Guardian_, 2035
* "Bedford's Yeovil Legacy" by Chris Spittles, _Yeovil Town F.C. Official Programme_, 2041
* "South Africa's Football Renaissance" by Luke Alfred, _Sports Illustrated Africa_, 2038
